table_definition:
create table public.user_otps (
  id uuid,
  user_id uuid,
  otp_code text,
  expires_at timestamp with time zone,
  verified boolean,
  created_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.application_video_assessment (
  id uuid,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  video_url text,
  transcript text,
  frames jsonb,
  status text,
  score real,
  rubrics jsonb,
  notify boolean
);

sample_row.transcript: If you've been learning math for a while, then you probably already know a thing or two about fractions. And if you've ever had to, well, break a cookie in half to share with a friend, well then you've used fractions in real life. Oh, well, thank you. That's because fractions are used to represent smaller pieces or parts of things. When you're first learning about fractions, it can help to draw pictures to see how they work. So let's start by drawing a circle. Now this circle represents what we call a hole. Now, not the kind of hole you can fall into. More like a whole cookie or a whole pizza. Now if we divide that circle, or whole amount, into four parts, then we call each of those parts a fraction of the original whole circle. Because this is math and not art, we can't just keep on drawing pictures. We need to learn how to write out fractions using the language of math. Yep… you guessed it… that means using numbers. Unlike a regular number, to write a fraction you need two numbers. One number on top, one number on bottom, and a line between them. I'll explain exactly what the line's for later in the video, but for now, let's figure out what those two numbers mean. Remember, fractions are used to represent parts of something. And the number on the bottom tells us how many parts that something is divided into. The number on top tells us how many of those parts we have. For example, let's write a fraction for our drawing here. I divided this circle into four parts, right? So the number on the bottom will be 4. And I still have all four of those parts, so the number on top will also be 4. I have 4 out of 4 parts. That means I still have a whole circle. But what if somebody came by and took away one part from the circle? Well, the circle's still divided into four parts, so the bottom number would still be 4. But I only have three of those parts left, so that means the top number will change to 3. So I have 3 over 4, or three-fourths of a circle. Make sense so far? Good! Let's try another example. Let's say that I divide a rectangle up into eight parts, and I give you three of those parts. Since the total number of parts is 8, the bottom number will be 8. And since you have three of those parts, the top number will be 3. So the fraction I'm giving you is 3 over 8, or three-eighths of the rectangle. No, no, no… no need to thank me. Oh, and it's important to remember that for fractions to work right, the parts that you divide the whole up into have to be equal. We can't like… well… take a candy bar and say, I'm gonna divide it into two parts, so this is your half, and here's my half. Let's look at a few more examples so you can really see the pattern of how fractions can represent parts of objects. This rectangle is divided up into three equal parts, and two of them are shaded red. So 2 over 3, or two-thirds of the rectangle, is shaded red. The circle is divided into 12 equal parts, and 7 of those parts are shaded green. So 7 over 12, or seven-twelfths of the circle, is shaded green. The hexagon is divided into 6 equal parts, and 5 of those parts are shaded blue. So 5 over 6, or five-sixths of the hexagon, is shaded blue. Alright, so you can see how fractions can be used to represent parts of objects like circles and rectangles. But fractions can be used for more than that. They can be used to represent parts of… well… anything. Like… like pets for example. Let's say you have 7 pets… 4 dogs, 2 cats, and a big fat hamster. Well that means that 4 over 7, or four-sevenths of your pets are dogs, and 2 over 7, or two-sevenths of your pets are cats, and 1 over 7, or one-seventh of your pets are hamsters. It also means that your house probably smells like a pet store. Okay, so fractions can be used to represent anything from parts of a circle to kitty cats. But did you know that fractions can also be used to represent things you can't even see? Well, like a test score for example. Let's say you take a math test and there's 20 questions on the test, and you get 17 of those questions right. That means that you got 17 over 20, or 17-twentieths of the questions right. Alright, so that's the basic idea of how fractions can be used to represent parts of things. But there's a lot more to fractions than that. In the next section, we're going to be looking at some of the other things we can do with fractions. But before that, let's review. Fractions are used to represent parts of a whole. Fractions are written in the form of a top number over a bottom number with a line between them. The bottom number represents how many parts the whole is divided into, and the top number represents how many of those parts you have. And finally, the parts that a whole is divided up into must be equal for fractions to work right. To really understand how fractions are used to represent parts of things, be sure to do the exercises. And I'll see you in section two. Learn more at www.mathantics.com

table_definition:
create table public.questionnaire_answers (
  id uuid,
  application_id uuid,
  answers_json jsonb,
  submitted_at timestamp without time zone,
  job_id uuid
);

create table public.admin_user_info (
  id uuid,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  first_name text,
  last_name text,
  school_id uuid,
  email text,
  phone_no text,
  avatar text,
  role user_role
);

create table public.jobs (
  id uuid,
  title text,
  job_type text,
  mode text,
  grade_levels text[],
  subjects text[],
  salary_range text,
  openings integer,
  job_description text,
  assessment_difficulty jsonb,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  school_id uuid,
  number_of_questions smallint,
  status text,
  minimum_passing_marks numeric,
  created_by uuid,
  demo_duration numeric,
  demo_passing_score numeric,
  assessment_type text,
  plan text,
  max_applications numeric,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.interview_attendees (
  id uuid,
  interview_schedule_id uuid,
  email text,
  name text,
  role text,
  response_status text,
  responded_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.job_application_status_events (
  id uuid,
  application_id uuid,
  old_status application_status,
  new_status application_status,
  changed_at timestamp with time zone,
  changed_by uuid
);

create table public.school_info (
  id uuid,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_by uuid,
  name text,
  location text,
  board text,
  address text,
  school_type text,
  num_students integer,
  num_teachers integer,
  website text,
  logo_url text,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.applicant_info (
  id uuid,
  user_id uuid,
  first_name text,
  email text,
  created_at timestamp without time zone,
  resume_url text,
  status text,
  last_name text,
  phone_number text,
  address text,
  city text,
  district text,
  state text,
  pin_code text,
  teaching_experience jsonb,
  education_qualifications jsonb,
  subjects text[],
  job_id uuid,
  resume_file_name text,
  avatar text,
  gender text
);

create table public.job_applications (
  id uuid,
  applicant_id uuid,
  job_id uuid,
  submitted_at timestamp without time zone,
  score integer,
  category_scores jsonb,
  created_at timestamp without time zone,
  status application_status,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone,
  detailed_results jsonb,
  overall jsonb,
  video_url text,
  user_id uuid,
  demo_score real
);

detailed_results.question: Which of the following is the most effective way to explain the concept of photosynthesis to middle school students?
When discussing a complex scientific topic, which communication technique is most effective for ensuring understanding?
Which digital tool would be most appropriate for creating an interactive quiz on the periodic table?
How can a teacher best incorporate technology to enhance a lesson on chemical reactions?
What is the primary purpose of using formative assessments in a science classroom?
In a lesson about the water cycle, which activity would best help students understand evaporation?
Which property of metals is most relevant when discussing why copper is used in electrical wiring?
Which of the following best describes the role of mitochondria in a cell?
During a lesson on ecosystems, a student asks why biodiversity is important. What is the best response?
Which teaching method would be most effective for a lesson on Newton's Laws of Motion?

table_definition:
create table public.application_questionnaires (
  id uuid,
  application_id uuid,
  questions_json jsonb,
  created_at timestamp without time zone,
  answer_json jsonb,
  job_id uuid
);

options: Using real-life examples like pizza slices
Lecturing on the theory of fractions
Reading from the textbook
Assigning more homework
questions_json.question: Which teaching strategy is most effective for helping students understand the concept of fractions?

options: Speak quickly to cover more material
Use simple language and visual aids
Dismiss questions for later
Encourage students to read the textbook independently
questions_json.question: How should a teacher communicate complex mathematical concepts to students with varying levels of understanding?

options: Microsoft Word
Google Forms
Adobe Photoshop
Notepad
questions_json.question: Which digital tool would be most effective for creating interactive math quizzes for middle school students?
What is the value of 'x' in the equation 3x + 5 = 20?

options: Discussing symmetry in nature
Memorizing definitions
Copying notes from the board
Assigning a research project
questions_json.question: Which of the following approaches is best for teaching students the concept of symmetry?

options: 80 degrees
85 degrees
90 degrees
100 degrees
questions_json.question: A triangle has angles measuring 45 degrees and 55 degrees. What is the measure of the third angle?

options: Using a geometry sketching software
Writing notes on a blackboard
Reading from a printed textbook
Drawing diagrams by hand
questions_json.question: How can a teacher best incorporate technology to enhance a lesson on geometry?

options: Giving a multiple-choice test
Asking students to write essays
Oral exams
Group discussions
questions_json.question: What is an effective way to assess students' understanding of algebraic expressions?

options: Pointing out the mistake and walking away
Explaining the correct method and guiding them through it
Ignoring the mistake
Telling them to try again without guidance
questions_json.question: If a student solves the equation x - 7 = 10 incorrectly, what is a constructive feedback method?
What is the greatest common divisor of 36 and 48?

table_definition:
create table public.offer_letters (
  id uuid,
  application_id uuid,
  job_id uuid,
  school_id uuid,
  offer_letter_url text,
  offer_message text,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_by uuid
);

sample_row.offer_message:
Dear Priya Sharma,

We are pleased to inform you that after careful consideration, we would like to extend an offer for the position of Mathematics Teacher at Shanti Niketan English Medium School.

Please find the attached offer letter for your review. If you have any questions or need clarification on any points, please don't hesitate to reach out.

We look forward to having you on our team!

Best regards,
rahuljainrj007luv@gmail.com

  name text,
  email text,
  phone text,
  school text,
  location text,
  selected_plan text,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  role text
);

);

Rajendra residency, New Hubli, Gantigeri
F 2

table_definition:
create table public.video_analyses (
  id uuid,
  video_url text,
  analysis_result jsonb,
  debug_info jsonb,
  processing_time_seconds numeric,
  frame_count integer,
  transcript_length integer,
  overall_score numeric,
  video_size_bytes bigint,
  has_visual_analysis boolean,
  created_at timestamp with time zone
);

meta.notes: The analysis is based solely on the transcript provided, which limits the assessment to audio-related categories. Visual elements such as eye contact and body language cannot be evaluated.

overall.summary: The transcript provided is too brief to assess subject knowledge, language fluency, or voice modulation. However, the sentence is grammatically correct, indicating strong grammar skills. The speaker also appears confident based on the concise and clear message.

evidence.confidence: The sentence is delivered clearly and concisely, suggesting confidence.
evidence.voice_modulation: Not assessable due to lack of content.
evidence.subject_knowledge: Not assessable due to lack of content.
evidence.grammar_sentence_structure: The sentence 'Thank you for watching!' is grammatically correct.
evidence.language_fluency_vocabulary: Not assessable due to lack of content.

red_flags: Insufficient content to assess most categories.
areas_for_improvement: Provide more content to assess subject knowledge.
Include varied vocabulary to evaluate language fluency.
Demonstrate voice modulation through varied pitch and pace.

table_definition:
create table public.trigger_log (
  id integer,
  trigger_name text,
  event text,
  row_data jsonb,
  created_at timestamp without time zone
);

detailed_results.question: Which of the following techniques is most effective for teaching vocabulary to primary students?
When giving feedback to young students, which approach is most appropriate?
Which tool would be most suitable for creating interactive English lessons for primary students?
A child in your class struggles to understand the concept of 'opposites'. Which activity would best help reinforce this concept?
How can a teacher encourage reading habits among primary students?
What is the best way to introduce a new storybook to young learners?
Which is an appropriate method to enhance listening skills in primary students?
What is a key component of clear communication when instructing young students?
Which activity best helps students learn sentence formation?
A teacher wants to use a digital platform to assign homework. Which tool is best suited for this task?

table_definition:
create table public.job_invitations (
  id uuid,
  job_id uuid,
  candidate_email text,
  invited_by uuid,
  invited_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.meet_generation_queue (
  id uuid,
  interview_id uuid,
  payload jsonb,
  processed boolean,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  processed_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.job_meeting_settings (
  id uuid,
  school_id uuid,
  default_interview_type text,
  default_duration text,
  candidate_reminder_hours text,
  interviewer_reminder_hours text,
  custom_instructions text,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  slots jsonb,
  job_id uuid
);

sample_row.custom_instructions: Please arrive 10 minutes early for your interview.

table_definition:
create table public.job_questionnaires (
  id uuid,
  questions_json jsonb,
  created_at timestamp without time zone,
  answer_json jsonb,
  job_id uuid
);

options: Using a textbook definition and asking students to memorize it
Demonstrating a simple daily task like making a sandwich and breaking it down into steps
Assigning a complex coding project to illustrate the use of algorithms
Giving a lecture on the history of algorithms without practical examples
questions_json.question: Which of the following is the most effective way to introduce the concept of algorithms to middle school students?

options: Ignore the email until the next class session
Reply promptly with a short, clear response addressing their question
Respond with a detailed lecture on the topic
Wait to address it in the next class without a written response
questions_json.question: A student sends you an email with a question outside of class hours. How should you respond to model effective communication?

options: It allows students to watch videos without attending live classes
It helps in organizing resources, assignments, and tracking student progress effectively
It replaces the need for teachers in the classroom
It is only beneficial for grading purposes
questions_json.question: What is the primary benefit of using a learning management system (LMS) in a computer science class?

options: Lecturing about binary arithmetic and asking students to take notes
Using an interactive online tool that visualizes the conversion between binary and decimal numbers
Providing a worksheet with binary operations to solve
Showing a documentary on the history of binary numbers
questions_json.question: In a lesson about binary numbers, what is an engaging way to help students understand the concept?

options: Explaining variables with complex mathematical equations
Creating a simple game using a visual coding platform where students use variables to store scores
Reading a chapter on variables from a textbook
Watching a video about famous programmers discussing variables
questions_json.question: Which activity would best help students understand the concept of variables in programming?

table_definition:
create table public.interview_schedule (
  id uuid,
  school_id uuid,
  candidate_email text,
  panelists jsonb,
  interview_date date,
  interview_time time without time zone,
  duration_minutes integer,
  type interview_type,
  meet_link text,
  google_event_id text,
  status interview_status,
  metadata jsonb,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_by uuid,
  job_id uuid,
  candidate_id uuid
);

create table public.interview_meeting_settings (
  id uuid,
  school_id uuid,
  default_interview_type text,
  default_duration text,
  buffer_time text,
  working_hours_start text,
  working_hours_end text,
  candidate_reminder_hours text,
  interviewer_reminder_hours text,
  custom_instructions text,
  working_days jsonb,
  breaks jsonb,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone,
  slots jsonb
);

sample_row.custom_instructions: Please arrive 10 minutes early for your interview.

table_definition:
create table public.interview_confirmations (
  id uuid,
  interview_id uuid,
  recipient_email text,
  recipient_type text,
  status text,
  response_token uuid,
  suggested_times jsonb,
  responded_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.interview_panelists (
  id uuid,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_by uuid,
  name text,
  email text,
  school_id uuid
);

create table public.interview_confirmation_emails (
  id uuid,
  interview_id uuid,
  sent_at timestamp with time zone,
  recipient_email text,
  status text,
  error_message text,
  retry_count integer
);

sample_row.message:
Hi Priya Sharma,

Thank you for applying to the Mathematics Teacher role at Shanti Niketan English Medium School. Unfortunately, we have decided not to proceed with your candidacy at this stage. We appreciate the effort behind your application, and understand that news like this is always disappointing, no matter where you are in the job search process. 


Thanks again for your interest in Shanti Niketan English Medium School and we wish you luck in your search.

Regards,
rahuljainrj007luv@gmail.com.
Shanti Niketan English Medium School

table_definition:
create table public.interview_rubrics (
  id uuid,
  school_id uuid,
  name text,
  description text,
  type text,
  out_of integer,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone,
  criterion_id text
);

sample_row.name: Subject Knowledge
sample_row.description: Depth of understanding and accuracy in the subject matter relevant to the grade/subject taught.

table_definition:
create table public.evaluation_tokens (
  id uuid,
  job_application_id uuid,
  panelist_email text,
  token text,
  expires_at timestamp with time zone,
  used boolean,
  used_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  rubric_id uuid,
  school_id uuid
);

create table public.panelist_evaluations (
  id uuid,
  job_application_id uuid,
  job_id uuid,
  school_id uuid,
  panelist_email text,
  scores jsonb,
  overall_score numeric,
  comments text,
  strengths text,
  areas_for_improvement text,
  recommendation text,
  submitted_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  token_id uuid
);

create table public.invitations (
  id uuid,
  school_id uuid,
  invited_by uuid,
  email text,
  name text,
  role text,
  token text,
  status text,
  expires_at timestamp with time zone,
  created_at timestamp with time zone,
  updated_at timestamp with time zone
);

create table public.application_ai_evaluations (
  id uuid,
  application_id uuid,
  final_recommendation text,
  strengths jsonb,
  areas_for_improvement jsonb,
  raw_payload jsonb,
  created_at timestamp with time zone
);

strengths: Good use of visuals to explain concepts.
Fluent language and strong eye contact.

rubrics.name: Subject Knowledge
rubrics.description: Depth of understanding and accuracy in the subject matter relevant to the grade/subject taught.

rubrics.name: Communication Clarity
rubrics.description: Ability to explain concepts clearly, use appropriate language level, and engage through articulation and tone.

rubrics.name: Pedagogical Approach
rubrics.description: Use of age-appropriate methods, questioning techniques, and differentiation strategies.

rubrics.name: Engagement & Interaction
rubrics.description: Encourages student participation, maintains attention, and adapts pacing dynamically.

rubrics.name: Confidence & Professional Demeanor
rubrics.description: Displays confidence, posture, and professionalism consistent with a role model teacher.

rubrics.name: Use of Teaching Aids / Technology
rubrics.description: Integrates blackboard, PPTs, or digital tools effectively to enhance clarity and retention.

rubrics.name: Language Proficiency
rubrics.description: Command over spoken English (and/or regional language), grammar, and pronunciation.

rubrics.name: Adaptability & Responsiveness
rubrics.description: Reacts well to unexpected questions, adapts examples or explanations in real time.

rubrics.name: Overall Teaching Effectiveness
rubrics.description: General impression of ability to deliver a high-quality lesson independently.

rubrics.name: Classroom Management
rubrics.description: Demonstrates control, structure, and positive reinforcement techniques suitable for maintaining learning discipline.

video_demo.transcript: If you've been learning math for a while, then you probably already know a thing or two about fractions. And if you've ever had to, well, break a cookie in half to share with a friend, well then you've used fractions in real life. Oh, well, thank you. That's because fractions are used to represent smaller pieces or parts of things. When you're first learning about fractions, it can help to draw pictures to see how they work. So let's start by drawing a circle. Now this circle represents what we call a hole. Now, not the kind of hole you can fall into. More like a whole cookie or a whole pizza. Now if we divide that circle, or whole amount, into four parts, then we call each of those parts a fraction of the original whole circle. Because this is math and not art, we can't just keep on drawing pictures. We need to learn how to write out fractions using the language of math. Yep… you guessed it… that means using numbers. Unlike a regular number, to write a fraction you need two numbers. One number on top, one number on bottom, and a line between them. I'll explain exactly what the line's for later in the video, but for now, let's figure out what those two numbers mean. Remember, fractions are used to represent parts of something. And the number on the bottom tells us how many parts that something is divided into. The number on top tells us how many of those parts we have. For example, let's write a fraction for our drawing here. I divided this circle into four parts, right? So the number on the bottom will be 4. And I still have all four of those parts, so the number on top will also be 4. I have 4 out of 4 parts. That means I still have a whole circle. But what if somebody came by and took away one part from the circle? Well, the circle's still divided into four parts, so the bottom number would still be 4. But I only have three of those parts left, so that means the top number will change to 3. So I have 3 over 4, or three-fourths of a circle. Make sense so far? Good! Let's try another example. Let's say that I divide a rectangle up into eight parts, and I give you three of those parts. Since the total number of parts is 8, the bottom number will be 8. And since you have three of those parts, the top number will be 3. So the fraction I'm giving you is 3 over 8, or three-eighths of the rectangle. No, no, no… no need to thank me. Oh, and it's important to remember that for fractions to work right, the parts that you divide the whole up into have to be equal. We can't like… well… take a candy bar and say, I'm gonna divide it into two parts, so this is your half, and here's my half. Let's look at a few more examples so you can really see the pattern of how fractions can represent parts of objects. This rectangle is divided up into three equal parts, and two of them are shaded red. So 2 over 3, or two-thirds of the rectangle, is shaded red. The circle is divided into 12 equal parts, and 7 of those parts are shaded green. So 7 over 12, or seven-twelfths of the circle, is shaded green. The hexagon is divided into 6 equal parts, and 5 of those parts are shaded blue. So 5 over 6, or five-sixths of the hexagon, is shaded blue. Alright, so you can see how fractions can be used to represent parts of objects like circles and rectangles. But fractions can be used for more than that. They can be used to represent parts of… well… anything. Like… like pets for example. Let's say you have 7 pets… 4 dogs, 2 cats, and a big fat hamster. Well that means that 4 over 7, or four-sevenths of your pets are dogs, and 2 over 7, or two-sevenths of your pets are cats, and 1 over 7, or one-seventh of your pets are hamsters. It also means that your house probably smells like a pet store. Okay, so fractions can be used to represent anything from parts of a circle to kitty cats. But did you know that fractions can also be used to represent things you can't even see? Well, like a test score for example. Let's say you take a math test and there's 20 questions on the test, and you get 17 of those questions right. That means that you got 17 over 20, or 17-twentieths of the questions right. Alright, so that's the basic idea of how fractions can be used to represent parts of things. But there's a lot more to fractions than that. In the next section, we're going to be looking at some of the other things we can do with fractions. But before that, let's review. Fractions are used to represent parts of a whole. Fractions are written in the form of a top number over a bottom number with a line between them. The bottom number represents how many parts the whole is divided into, and the top number represents how many of those parts you have. And finally, the parts that a whole is divided up into must be equal for fractions to work right.
